news_summary: Anonymizing applications has improved equitable access to equipment time for postdocs, promoting fairness in research opportunities.
news_summary_fr: L'anonymisation des candidatures a permis d'améliorer l'accès équitable au temps d'utilisation des équipements pour les postdocs, favorisant ainsi l'équité dans les opportunités de recherche.
news_summary_es: La anonimización de las solicitudes ha mejorado el acceso equitativo al tiempo de equipo para los postdoctorales, fomentando la equidad en las oportunidades de investigación.

articles.title: Postdocs get more equipment time when applications are anonymized
articles.summary: Nature, Published online: 28 July 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-02356-6Early-career researchers’ access to neutron-beam instruments jumped from 61% to 78% at one Australian facility.
articles.content:
More postdoctoral researchers secured access to sophisticated scientific instruments when an Australian facility made their application process anonymous1.

The results of the intervention, reported in Research Evaluation this month, are the latest example of how introducing blind review, in which the identities of the applicants are not revealed, can reduce systemic biases.

Blind review shifts the scrutiny away from the scientist to the science, says Priyamvada Natarajan, a theoretical astrophysicist at Yale University in New Haven, Connecticut, who was involved in a similar effort at NASA’s Hubble Space Telescope. “If the idea is original and brilliant, it shouldn’t matter who wrote it,” she says. “Everyone should have a fair shot.”

The latest study suggests that reviewers can have a “prestige bias” towards experienced or well-known researchers, says John Carpenter, who studies protoplanetary disks at the Joint ALMA Observatory in Santiago. This can result in these researchers being offered equipment time at the expense of their less-experienced peers. The effect permeates across fields, says Carpenter, who analysed data on a similar effort at the Atacama Large Millimeter/submillimeter Array (ALMA). “It’s not just telescopes.”

System overhaul

Data on applications to use the Hubble Space Telescope and ALMA2 showed that women and less-experienced applicants got more facility time after blind review was introduced. Over the past few years, the practice has since become more widespread — particularly at observatories, including the James Webb Space Telescope and the European Southern Observatory’s telescopes in northern Chile.

Isabelle Kingsley, a gender equity research previously at the University of New South Wales, in Sydney, who now works for SAGE, an Australian initiative that campaigns for equity and diversity in education and research, wanted to see whether similar interventions could work in a range of scientific facilities.

She and her colleagues launched trials at four Australian facilities, which manage optical and radio telescopes, neutron-beam instruments and high-performance computing systems. In applications to use the resources, applicants were asked not to include their names and affiliations. One facility was hesitant about committing fully to anonymization and decided to include first initials and last names of applicants at the back of applications.

The researchers analysed the outcomes of more than 4,500 applications, including ones made up to five years before the intervention and up to two years after it.

Postdoc boost

The Australian Centre for Neutron Scattering, in Lucas Heights, manages 15 neutron-beam instruments, and was one of two facilities that collected data on career stage. After introducing blind review, success rates for postdoctoral researchers rose from 61% to 78%. Success rates for PhD, graduate and undergraduate students remained stable, but those for more-experienced researchers dropped from 61% to 50%. In the other facility that collected data on career stage, postdocs’ time on the equipment remained around 75%.

The results suggest that “anonymization can level the playing field” and help to open doors, says Kingsley. And because early-career researchers tend to be more diverse, in terms of their gender and cultural background, improving their outcomes contributes to retaining diverse scientific talent, she says.
articles.reasoning: Anonymizing applications for equipment time has increased access for early-career researchers, promoting fairness and equal opportunity in scientific research. This change supports merit-based access and helps reduce bias, which is a positive development for the research community.
articles.personality_title: Postdocs get more equipment time with anonymous applications
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context**
Early-career researchers, like postdocs, often compete for limited time on high-tech scientific instruments. These tools are crucial for advancing their studies, but bias in the selection process can unfairly limit access.

**What happened**
An Australian research facility changed its application process by removing the names of the applicants. This method, called blind review, focuses on the quality of the science rather than who is applying. As a result, the number of postdocs granted access to neutron-beam instruments rose from 61% to 78%.

**Impact**
This shift means more early-career scientists can use important equipment, helping to level the playing field. It reduces bias and promotes fairness, allowing talented researchers to succeed based on their ideas and work, not their identity.

**What's next step**
Other research centers are encouraged to adopt anonymous application processes. Continued use of blind review can further open doors for diverse scientists and improve fairness in access to crucial research tools.

**One-sentence takeaway**
Making applications anonymous helps early-career researchers get fairer access to important scientific equipment, boosting opportunities for everyone.
articles.personality_title_fr: Les postdoctorants obtiennent plus de temps d'équipement grâce aux candidatures anonymes
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte**
Les chercheurs en début de carrière, comme les postdoctorants, se disputent souvent un temps limité sur des instruments scientifiques de haute technologie. Ces outils sont essentiels pour faire avancer leurs études, mais des biais dans le processus de sélection peuvent limiter injustement l'accès.

**Ce qui s'est passé**
Un centre de recherche australien a modifié son processus de candidature en supprimant les noms des candidats. Cette méthode, appelée revue à l’aveugle, se concentre sur la qualité de la science plutôt que sur l'identité des postulants. Résultat : la part des postdoctorants ayant accès aux instruments à faisceau de neutrons est passée de 61 % à 78 %.

**Impact**
Ce changement permet à davantage de jeunes chercheurs d’utiliser des équipements importants, favorisant ainsi l’égalité des chances. Il réduit les biais et encourage l’équité, permettant aux chercheurs talentueux de réussir en fonction de leurs idées et travaux, pas de leur identité.

**Prochaine étape**
D’autres centres de recherche sont encouragés à adopter des processus de candidature anonymes. L’utilisation continue de la revue à l’aveugle peut ouvrir davantage de portes aux scientifiques diversifiés et améliorer l’équité d’accès aux outils de recherche essentiels.

**En une phrase**
Rendre les candidatures anonymes aide les jeunes chercheurs à obtenir un accès plus juste aux équipements scientifiques importants, augmentant les opportunités pour tous.
articles.personality_title_es: Los postdoctorados consiguen más tiempo de equipo con solicitudes anónimas
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto**
Los investigadores en etapas tempranas, como los postdoctorados, compiten por el tiempo limitado en instrumentos científicos de alta tecnología. Estas herramientas son clave para avanzar en sus estudios, pero los sesgos en el proceso de selección pueden limitar injustamente el acceso.

**Qué pasó**
Un centro de investigación australiano cambió su proceso de solicitud eliminando los nombres de los candidatos. Este método, llamado revisión anónima, se enfoca en la calidad de la ciencia en lugar de en quién aplica. Como resultado, el porcentaje de postdoctorados con acceso a instrumentos de haz de neutrones aumentó del 61% al 78%.

**Impacto**
Este cambio significa que más científicos jóvenes pueden usar equipos importantes, nivelando las oportunidades. Reduce los sesgos y promueve la equidad, permitiendo que los investigadores talentosos tengan éxito basado en sus ideas y trabajo, no en su identidad.

**Próximo paso**
Se anima a otros centros de investigación a adoptar procesos de solicitud anónimos. El uso continuo de la revisión anónima puede abrir aún más puertas a científicos diversos y mejorar la equidad en el acceso a herramientas de investigación cruciales.

**Conclusión en una frase**
Hacer anónimas las solicitudes ayuda a que los investigadores en etapas tempranas tengan un acceso más justo a equipos científicos importantes, aumentando las oportunidades para todos.
